repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: This weird option is never used and any value other than the default causes highly irregular behavior and is a remnant of the far distant past.

comment_data.body: Do all tests fail here even if skipping the unsupported behavior?

This seems to be a test of the generic idea of a commalist option. Do we have similar tests for other options that are equally comprehensive (otherwise this could be findreplaced into a test for some other option with at least four valid values)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,3 +1,8 @@
+" 'backspace' is removed #15484
+if has('nvim')
+  finish
+endif
+
 " Tests for 'backspace' settings
 
 func Test_backspace_option()

comment_data.body:
See also

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/15484/files#diff-d6ab96f29571f8965add2c71d890dc13bdae9e2653b01620e5d281ceffd376e4L641-R643

and

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/15484/files#diff-6d7ef04f38f6f82559796fd15bfdc2d93485623d6ada5d9f89d660b2c48d13f5L190-R192

So we are still covering comma list options.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,3 +1,8 @@
+" 'backspace' is removed #15484
+if has('nvim')
+  finish
+endif
+
 " Tests for 'backspace' settings
 
 func Test_backspace_option()

comment_data.body: True, thinking more of it, this separate test is only needed due to the weird number/string hybrid nature of 'backspace' option (which is a small point in favor of removing it)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,3 +1,8 @@
+" 'backspace' is removed #15484
+if has('nvim')
+  finish
+endif
+
 " Tests for 'backspace' settings
 
 func Test_backspace_option()

comment_data.body: Supported behavior in `Test_backspace_ctrl_u passes for me. `Test_backspace_option` can be skipped instead.

comment_regular_data.body: Link to an existing discussion/issue like https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/6289 and discuss this before creating an aggressive refactor.

Interesting idea. Are the differences with upstream tests, worth the code savings  ?

I see @janlazo is not in favor, what's your thinking?

> Interesting idea. Are the differences with upstream tests, worth the code savings ?

I did of course try to keep the diffs with upstream tests as small as possible, though I suspect these diffs won't be very troublesome moving forward. Essentially, anything that mentions the `'backspace'` option in any future merge conflicts can just be removed.

Treat it like `set encoding=utf-8` so configs that use the supported behavior don't fail and the option  value can be debugged.

This PR modified Vim's tests by deleting, not commenting, lines so porting patches will be (slightly) harder. Tests that depend on unsupported `backspace` values should be skipped via `:throw` or commands,functions in `check.vim` instead of silent `return`.

> Treat it like set encoding=utf-8 so configs that use the supported behavior don't fail and the option value can be debugged.

Understood, I can do this, but:

> Tests that depend on unsupported backspace values should be skipped via :throw or commands,functions in check.vim instead of silent return.

There is no `Check` command to test for an existing option that can only take a specified value (there is `CheckOption`, but that won't work since we're keeping the option). So I can 1) make a new `Check` command/function for this use-case, 2) make a generic `Check` command/function to test for any arbitrary condition (or that some command doesn't throw an error), or 3) continue to just use `if has('nvim')` statements and `return`s. What would be your preference?

**EDIT:** It may be a moot point. I changed `'backspace'` to work like `'encoding'` and this greatly reduced the diff in the Vim tests. Hopefully this is a bit more maintainable moving forward.
I have 'set backspace=2' in my vimrc and now init.vim, I think I changed/added this some 20y ago (for vim). Will this change break me or is '2' the default?

> I have 'set backspace=2' in my vimrc and now init.vim, I think I changed/added this some 20y ago (for vim). Will this change break me or is '2' the default?

2 is the default: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/15484/files#diff-d6d91fad5f121deeeca8f75cd068a7fc4e0685b194d46be979c84b6f4fee3b1aR2958

~~If you don't know why you set the option or what it resolves to, presumably you'll be happy with the default of `backspace=indent,eol,start`. However, in your init.vim you will get an error if you try to `:set backspace` since it is read-only after this PR. If you are trying to use the same config for Vim, you can guard it like this:~~

[ Quoting ***@***.***> in "Re: [neovim/neovim] refactor(edit)!..." ]
>    I have 'set backspace=2' in my vimrc and now init.vim, I think I changed/
>    added this some 20y ago (for vim). Will this change break me or is '2' the
>    default?
>
>If you don't know why you set the option or what it resolves to, presumably
>you'll be happy with the default of backspace=indent,eol,start. However, in
>your init.vim you will get an error if you try to :set backspace since it is
>read-only after this PR. If you are trying to use the same config for Vim, you
>can guard it like this:
>
>if !has('nvim')
>  set backspace=2
>endif

thanks.

I've just checked, but '2' is equal to the above default:

       For backwards compatibility with version 5.4 and earlier:
         value   effect
           0     same as ":set backspace=" (Vi compatible)
           1     same as ":set backspace=indent,eol"
           2     same as ":set backspace=indent,eol,start"
           3     same as ":set backspace=indent,eol,nostop"

Using `set backspace=2` will still work (but no other number value), it just won't do anything. I kept the ability to use a number since there are multiple Vim tests that use it this way and this reduces the number of changes from upstream.
Are the non-number values still working? I set `backspace=indent`only, and it's one of my favorite settings in vim.

> I use backspace=indent. Each insert command is an isolated edit for me.

That makes sense, I can see that being useful. I think we should keep this option.
Yes I'm afraid I agree, especially after seeing the early results of that poll that showed that far more people than I expected (apparently) still use this option.

At least we know now. It's important that we listen to users when there are actual use-cases, and weigh that against the potential gains. There are some gains here, but not enough to justify the removal.

Thanks for the exploration though, @gpanders .

I'll throw my use case in just in case this comes up again:

Coming from a vi background in the mid-1990s, insert mode was such that it only added text. My mental model of what's going on with `.` could always be assumed to insert text, and never destroy any text.

I tried the other backspace settings in vim in the late 90s, but found they were too destructive. I often accidentally backspaced over the first character in my insert and was forced to `<esc>` and undo, but if I deleted exactly the right amount (all of the newly inserted text and no more), then undo undid the previous edit, which was not the intention. Undo became unreliable.

I went with `backspace=indent` because, at about this same time, vim started adding auto-indention stuff, and I considered that "adding text".

So why not `backspace=eol`? I'm really used to the idea that every line is kind of an independent space to work on, and they should only be joined or crossed if explicitly intended to do so. `<Enter>` can only add lines, so it's an ok as an explicit action, but `<Backspace>` could delete chars as well, so the compound role of delete AND join left me irked.

I realize that backspace=2 is very comfortable for people coming from non-vi editors, but by removing this option, you are destroying a part of the original spark of vi. Maybe dinosaurs like myself will all die off if you keep `backspace=2` as the default, but removing it would send neovim in a direction that says to me: "neovim does not get vi".

One last thing.. thanks for doing that survey. I would have been very sad to find this gone, and going back to vim is an option I would have dreaded.

Revisiting this, as this cropped up in our on-going refactor of the options code (which will enable a number of very fancy improvements, like true dict options): The "backwards compatibility" number values significantly complicate the code, so it would be great to be able to remove that **while keeping the `backspace` option** per se. All that means is that instead of 
```vim
set backspace=1
```
you'd have to use
```vim
set backspace=indent,eol
```
in your config. That would be a (documented) breaking change, but massively simplify the refactor.

Any objections to that? Vim 5.4 was a hot minute ago, after all ;)

(Posting this here since that will ping a number of users with a vested interest.)

As long as there is a way to get to the behavior, I personally don't care if I have to change a config file setting. Just make it well documented in the change log. The magic numbers are not great, so it's good they die.

I don't want to have to think about what setting I have and what it needs to become, so a good mapping documented would be good.
If you didn't use any of the magic numbers (which from your previous comment I don't think you do), you wouldn't have to change anything.

title: refactor(edit)!: remove 'backspace' option
